page.title: 12Ecology(2) in Leverton
page.content: The smaller common British birds are well represented in the area and have generally thriving populations.The larger birds particularly owls and falcons have made a very slow comeback as attitudes and the laws have changed.Members of the owl family present in the village include barn owls,tawny and little owls with winter visits by occasional long-eared and short-eared owls.There are at least two pairs of kestrels nesting in the village and harriers,peregrines and sometimes ospreys are winter visitors. Several rare visitors have been seen in recent years including great grey shrike,jays and a hooded crow.Magpies are beginning to return to the area after an absence of about ten years because otherwise our only representative of the crows is the jackdaw.
